Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative: Documenting the Occurrence through Space & Time of Aquatic Non-indigenous Fish, Mollusks, Algae, & Plants Threatening North America's Great
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the greatest threats to the health of North America's Great Lakes is invasion by exotic species, several of which already have had catastrophic impacts on property values, the fisheries, shipping, and tourism industries, and continue to threaten the survival of native species and wetland ecosystems. Additional species have been placed on watchlists because of their potential to become aquatic invasives. This project will create a network of herbaria and zoology museums from among the Great Lakes states of MN, WI, IL, IN, MI, OH, and NY to better document the occurrence of these species in space and time by imaging and providing online access to the information on the specimens of the critical organisms. Several initiatives are already in place to alert citizens to the dangers of spreading aquatic invasives among our nation's waterways, but this project will develop complementary scientific and educational tools for scientists, students, wildlife officers, teachers, and the public who have had little access to images or data derived directly from preserved specimens collected over the past three centuries.

This bi-national Thematic Collections Network of >25 institutions from eight states and Canada will digitize 1.73 million historical specimens representing 2,550 species of exotic fish, clams, snails, mussels, algae, plants, and their look-alikes documented to occur in the Great Lakes Basin. It is one of the first efforts to digitize liquid preserved specimens and to integrate cross-kingdom taxa and these methods could become national standards for cross taxon digitization. Students will be provided with hands-on experience in modern methods of specimen curation and this cross-taxon network will provide greater flexibility to existing web platforms for integration of data. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the greatest threats to the health of North America’s five Great Lakes is invasion by exotic species, several of which already have had catastrophic impacts on property values, the fisheries, shipping, and tourism industries.  Attempts have been made to eradicate some of these invasives, but they continue to threaten the survival of native species and wetland ecosystems.  For most cases of invasion, biologists know little about the source, point of invasion, direction and timing of invasions, or possibility that unrelated organisms may have invaded together or via similar routes. Look-alike native species are often confused with exotics, but may also hybridize with them to create ‘super weeds’. Historical museum specimens held within natural history collections, especially those in the Upper Midwest, provide unparalleled information about invasive species and their closest relatives across time and space.  Many were collected >100 years ago.  The physical specimens themselves can provide data regarding variation in form and even genetics of specimens decades or more in age.

 

During the course of this project a bi-national thematic collections network of >20 institutions from eight states and Canada successfully digitized 1,039,000 historical specimens of fish, mollusks and plant specimens. This process involved applying unique barcode labels to each specimen, photographing them using standard methodologies, converting locality information into latitude and longitude coordinates (i.e., georeferencing), and uploading all of these data records and images into online, open-access, internet data portals.  Specifically, all data was aggregated into the Great Lakes Invasive Portal: www.greatlakesinvasives.org, and these were harvested subsequently by the USA national iDigBio Portal: www.idigbio.org.  In addition, the botanical specimens alone were further incorporated into a newly created regional collaborative Midwest Consortium of Herbaria Portal: www.midwestherbaria.org.    

 

Since this was one of the first efforts to digitize specimens across different kingdoms, phyla, and classes [flowering plants + bony fish + lampreys + snails + bivalve mollusks] it required development of new methods of digitization.  Plant specimens tend to be flat and easy to photograph.  Mollusks are usually dry, but three-dimensional, and vary in morphology between top and bottom of bivalve shells.  Fish are most often stored whole in alcohol-based liquid preservative, making them especially difficult to photograph.  Protocols and methods of best-practice for digitizing these unique collections were developed, tested, and shared with the greater natural history museums community. Furthermore, our data portal was the first to serve information across different groups of life and required customized software programming.  In total 762,725 plant specimens were newly digitized, 107,712 fish were newly digitized, and 45,991 mollusk specimens were newly digitized for this project.  An additional 122,143 plant specimens were incorporated into the data portal from Canadian partners.   

 

Finally, scientists engaged in this Thematic Collections Network showcased the project and its derivative products at a number of national conferences, and developed educational outreach tools for the public.  Among these are a portable Exploratory Station (available to schools and libraries from the Field Museum) and a series of 26 Species Identification guides available online that are intended to teach citizens how to recognize an invasive aquatic plant species from harmless native look-alike species.
